#Text=Anna Notaras
#Text=Anna Notaras Palaiologina ( Greek : Ἄννα Νοταρᾶ Παλαιολογίνα ; died 8 July 1507 ) was the daughter of Loukas Notaras , the last megas doux of the Byzantine Empire .
#Text=Biography

#Text=Anna probably left Constantinople prior to fall of Constantinople in 1453 , although the passenger manifest of a Genoese ship which escaped the siege on the morning of the 29th May includes two entries for the family name Notaras . [ 1 ]
#Text=Her exact whereabouts before 1459 are not certain , but in that year she appeared in Italy and made claim to the Notaras family inheritance , held at the Bank of St George in Genoa .
#Text=The fate of this large inheritance had become a diplomatic question during the six years following the death of Loukas Notaras .
#Text=She had her younger brother , Jacob Notaras , disinherited on the grounds that he had converted to Islam while in captivity . [ 2 ]
#Text=She lived for a time in Rome before eventually settling in Venice , where she became the center of the Byzantine expatriate community . [ 3 ]

#Text=She repeatedly petitioned the Republic to allow the construction of an Orthodox church within Venice ( something not granted until 1539 ) and when the Council of Ten prevaricated , she badgered them into a compromise , allowing her to build an oratory within her own sizable Casa and hold Orthodox services within it from 1475 . [ 3 ]
#Text=In 1498 , the Venetian Senate finally granted their Greek community the right to found the Scuola di San Nicolò dei Greci , a confraternity which aided members of that community .
#Text=Although Anna Notaras died in 1507 , prior to the completion of San Giorgio dei Greci , she left three of icons in her will to the church , where they remain today .
#Text=In 1499 , the first exclusively Greek printing press in Venice began operation under the direction of Nikolaos Vlasto and Zacharias Kalliergis .
#Text=The first product of the press was the Etymologicum Magnum and the dedication at the front thanks the ‘ most modest lady Anna , daughter of…Loukas Notaras ’ who had defrayed its cost . [ 3 ]

#Text=In 1472 Anna began negotiations with the council of Siena to take possession of the old castle of Montauto and the surrounding lands in order to found a commune where Greeks could live " according to their laws and customs " .
#Text=In their correspondence with her , the council referred to her as the widow of the last Byzantine emperor , Constantine XI Palaiologos ( r.1449 – 1453 ) , but this was untrue .
#Text=There is no mention of such a marriage in any other contemporary source , especially in the writings of George Sphrantzes , his chancellor .
#Text=Although the legal contract was drawn up , the commune project went no further . [ 3 ]
#Text=A friend of Basilios Bessarion , Anna also recovered several Greek manuscripts from the east .
#Text=In 1470 she acquired a 12th century manuscript Catena of Job written for the Grand Duke of Cyprus .

#Text=On March 2 , 1489 , Zabeta , wife of her brother Jacob , filed a petition before the judges of the Venetian Procurator alleging that Jacob had shortly before his death in Ancona , sent to his sister Anna " a box of law books of different kinds , both on parchment and on paper " of great value .
#Text=She demanded that Anna hand over these works to her , or be ordered to pay her the sum of 120 ducats .
#Text=Anna acknowledged receipt of this box but contended that most of the books had actually been bought by herself and been lent to Jacob .

#Text=Anna won this court case and then on 8th of May , 1490 , Anna filed a petition against Zabeta , alleging that she had entered the Ca Notaras and stolen a valuable copy of Petrarch , which Anna had bought from Thomas Palaiologos in 1462 , during his visit to Venice , which she valued at 51 ducats .
#Text=The judge ruled in Anna 's favour again . [ 4 ]
#Text=Fictional Portrayals
#Text=Novels
#Text=Anna Notaras appears as a central character in The Dark Angel by Mika Waltari and Porphyry and Ash by Peter Sandham
